abstracts.cdata!:
The project also provides lessons about
            the key elements for the success of a reform program. These
            include: (1) Shared vision of institutional reforms and high
            level commitment and strong ownership of reforms among key
            policy makers: There was strong commitment from management
            of the implementation agencies and ownership for the reforms
            within the departments. This permeated to the lower levels
            of  the department - a sign that change management was
            taking place. (2) Strong inter-agency cooperation: Strong
            cooperation between the oversight agencies and the
            implementing department also helped in the success of the
            project. Prior to project implementation, there were some
            signs of distrust among the line departments and the
            oversight agencies. Working together during the project
            implementation through a joint steering committee helped
            create an  understanding of the various constraints faced by
            the various agencies in performing their tasks. Regular
            meetings to discuss and solve these problems led to a
            stronger cooperation between these agencies. It in turn
            helped the oversight agencies identify champions for
            government-wide reform. (3) Alignment of objectives of the
            project with the goals of the agencies involved: In 1999,
            the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) which is
            responsible for managing the budget, public sector
            compensation policy and organizational  management was
            initiating a government-wide public expenditure management
            improvement program at the time the project design was
            developed. At the same time, the Commission on Audit (COA)
            which issues accounting rules and regulation in addition to
            conducting financial audit was beginning to conduct value
            for money audits and working with civil society groups on
            participatory audits. The focus of these two agencies  were
            improvements in financial management and reporting,
            increased accountability and efficiency in  budget
            execution, and improved public sector performance in all
            government agencies and departments were clearly aligned
            with the objective of the project. (4) Civil society and
            community involvement: Civil society and community
            involvement through the joint monitoring of the school
            building program, the increased role of Parent
            Teacher's Community Associations (PTCAs) in the
            rehabilitation of schools, the civil society monitoring of
            the delivery of textbooks was crucial in improving civil
            society opinions about the government processes. Prior to
            the project, allegations of graft and corruption in
            procurement in the social sectors had created a sense of
            distrust among civil society. Another important lesson
            learned is that institutional reform is a long term process
            and needs to be accompanied by change management.

4647536.trustfund:
TF025937-PHRD-SOCIAL SECTOR MANAGEMENT
            IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM,TF037639-PHILIPPINES - HEALTH SECTOR ASSESSMENT

repnme.cdata!: Extending social services throughout the Philippines

abstracts.cdata!:
In the aftermath of the Asian Financial
            Crisis, the Philippines health and education sectors were
            scrambling for resources. In 1998, spending on
            educationtextbooks, classroom desks and chairs for
            students, and training programs for teachersdwindled to a
            new low. The Department of Health spent only 25 percent of
            its budget on drugs and medicine. These developments led to
            a serious deterioration in the quality and accessibility of
            basic social services. The World Bank-funded Social
            Expenditure Management Project, approved in 2000, supported
            the governments provision of basic social services to the
            poorest parts of the country. About 375,000 families in
            3,700 villages have been assisted through the program. The
            loan also helped to maintain and operate centers,
            institutions and programs for distressed and disadvantaged
            groups, serving about 33,000 children; 9,000 adolescents;
            40,000 women; and 5,000 persons with disabilities.

            throughout the Philippines

5086157.trustfund:
TF025937-PHRD-SOCIAL SECTOR MANAGEMENT
            IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM,TF037639-PHILIPPINES - HEALTH SECTOR ASSESSMENT
5086157.majtheme: Public sector governance,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Expenditure Management
            Project will support basic social services, during the
            difficult fiscal period following the East Asian financial
            crisis, and significant improvements to public expenditure
            management in social sectors, will be introduced. There are
            two main components: 1) The protection of basic social
            services, comprises selected on-going programs in the
            Education, and Social Welfare Departments, largely
            benefiting the poor. Quality improvement of basic education
            include the provision of textbooks, and teacher manuals,
            complemented by teacher training assistance. In addition,
            construction, repair, and, maintenance of classrooms will be
            implemented, and, needed equipment - desks and chairs - will
            be supplied. Social assistance for disadvantaged groups,
            will be provided through: a) the Comprehensive Integrated
            Delivery of Social Services, who will provide basic needs
            through a demand-driven approach, targeting the poorest
            municipalities; b) the Maintenance and Operation of Centers
            and Institutions, will focus on orphanages and centers for
            the handicapped; while, c) the Assistance Program for
            Distressed and Disadvantaged Populations will include
            programs for special groups. 2) An integrated technical
            assistance package will strengthen management capacity, and
            information systems, developing appropriate systems, and
            providing on-the-job training capabilities.
